Sanding/polishing metal/plastic/glass tip: This works better for hand sanding/polishing. Alternate the direction of sanding when you change grits, that way, you can see when the scratch pattern from the previous grit is all gone, and you can move on to the next grit.
Example: You start with 100grit, going up and down, creating a vertical scratch pattern. When you go to the next grit, say 200 grit, you go from left to right, and when all the vertical scratches from the 100grit are gone, and all you have is horizontal, 200grit scratches, you can then move on to the next grit, say 400grit, and start going up and down again, creating a new vertical scratch pattern to cover the previous horizontal, 200 grit scratch pattern. Rinse, and repeat. (Literally, you want to make sure you get all the courser grit off when switching grits.

1. You didn’t season it correctly. Way too much oil at the start. Just wet a paper towel with oil, rub it on until everything is coated, (you need to work it around a while to get it fully coated) then bake the skillet at 400F. Then let it cool, then do it again. You don’t want a thick buildup of oil - that’ll make things stick, and make the oil flake off the way it did. If you can dig your fingernail into the oil, or if it feels at all gummy, you did it wrong - too much oil.
2. Cook the egg properly. First, your pan is toooo hot! Put some oil or butter down first. Butter should just slightly sizzle when it hits the pan. If it does more than that, wipe it off, reduce the heat and wait. When the heat is right, drop the butter, quick sizzle, butter melts... Then drop your egg right in the center of the butter. If the butter turns brown, your pan is either too hot or you waited too long to drop your egg.
3. Get a real spatula- made of metal. Thin. That plastic club you’re using for a spatula shouldn’t be used for anything you need to flip. Ever. 😂

If you get it seasoned correctly, it’ll feel slicker than teflon when it’s clean. When you’re done using it, wipe it clean with a paper towel, then wet a paper towel with oil and rub it on the surface.
Soap and water should never need to touch that pan. If something you cooked is sticking, you there is something wrong in your process- either the seasoning is wrong, your cooking method or temperature is wrong, or your maintenance is wrong. If that is happening, scour off the buildup to bare metal, and start over.

Most people either use too much oil to “season,” use too much heat when cooking, aren’t using appropriate cooking techniques, or all of the above. Very few actually get this right - but when you do finally get it right, you know, because it’s not just a nice cooking surface - it’s by far and away the greatest cooking surface you’ve ever experienced. If you aren’t blown away by how well it works, and if it’s not blowing away the performance of your teflon coated pans, you’re doing something wrong 😉 And if you learn to get it right, I promise, you’ll love it.

•Proper cast iron seasoning consists of polymerized oils (which is oil that becomes a type of plastic entity when exposed to high temperatures) that fill in the bumps left by the sand mold, like pouring concrete over rough stones.

•Flaxseed oil is mostly for show since it leaves a blacker patina but will chip. Canola oil or another neutral cooking oil works well. Animal fats like bacon grease work well, but there's a chance they could turn rancid.

•Pouring cold water on a hot pan will cause thermal shock and possibly damage your pan through cracking and warping. Use the hottest water temperature available or let your pan cool slightly before rinsing it

•Even if your pan is glass-smooth, you still need oil, just like stainless steel and Teflon.

•It's recommended that you heat up cast iron in the oven or on low-medium heat for a short period before cooking with it.

•Scrubbing with any cleaning supply isn't recommended as it can damage the seasoning. Try dish soap or kosher salt with a special chainmail scrubber or a soft nylon brush. Lodge as well as other companies sell the chainmail scrubber and nylon brush. DO NOT USE ANYTHING WITH LYE!

•To season your pan to a glass finish, just cook with it as much as possible. Wash your pan with hot water, gently scrub off with food with kosher salt or a small amount of dish soap and a chainmail/nylon scrubber, and rinse it. Dry it with a lint-free towel, such as microfiber, and put it on the stove at high heat to evaporate any remaining water as well as open the cast iron's porous surface. After it's been heated, coat it with a small layer of oil or fat, such as Crisco. Then store it in a dry place until you use it again.
Note: from experience. Turn on your oven exhaust fan when you season it, or you will trip the smoke alarms in the next room over.

Dude, seriously... I know there are a lot of posts about your method of "cooking" and "cleaning" your cast iron pan. Always cook with some sort of fat when using cast iron, ESPECIALLY WHEN COOKING EGGS! As for cleaning pouring water on a hot skillet is actually a great technique, NEVER COLD WATER. Get the water as hot as possible, preferably hot enough to burn you then run the skillet under the water, then gently rub it with something soft like a clean rag, all the stuck on bits of food should be steamed off with this method. If some bits remain reheat the pan and repeat the above steps, then heat one final time and wipe it down with the flax oil, very thin layer, and let it cool on the stove top. Cold water on hot cast iron is a great way to crack your pan. I hope this helps.

Your pan has not been properly seasoned.

You could sort of season it by simply repeatedly applying oil, heating it, and allowing it to cool.

However; you've made the process an order of magnitude more difficult by polishing it.

I realize the mirror surface was the point, and I'm not saying you are totally off base, but you need to give the oil a more porous surface to which to bond.

Best way to do this would probably be to get the raw polished surface wet, then let it rust.

Red rust is FE2O3.

If left alone, aside from being distasteful, it will continue to oxidize the metal.

What you would do at that point is first use some 2000 grit to smooth the surface, then heat the pan on the stove to a dull glow, then let it cool.

The red surface should have turned black.

This is FE3O4, or magnetite.

This is both a naturally occurring mineral, as well as what tubes in high pressure steam boilers are coated with internally.

It is much more stable than red rust, and as long as it is not manually disturbed, or exposed to fairly strong acid, it will remain bonded to the metal and act as a corrosion barrier.

It has a slick, dense feel on it's own, but it's actually a lot more porous than raw iron.

In boiler tubes, this layer is created initially by running the boiler at low temp (300F or so) and low pressure.

Not something easily replicated at home

Low is relative - main propulsion boilers operate at about 900F and 1200 psi.

You should repeat this process a few times to get a rugged base sand just enough each time to knock off the high points.

Sort of like the process of painting/sanding a car if you want 20 layers of Candy Apple Red.

Once you have established the desired magnetite layer, you can then oil it and heat it repeatedly to establish your cooking surface.

Any bare metal pan needs oil, a few millimeters of it. Also, the oil needs to be as hot as it can be, before adding the eggs.

When you season cast iron, the oil should be wiped on, then polished off so there is just an extremely thin film of oil on the surface, then the piece should be put upside-down into the oven to "cook".

Too high heat will burn the oil and not seal the metal correctly; the temperature should only be high enough (400-425°F) to bond the oil with the iron, not form a layer of burnt oil scum, which is what this was.

If the surface feels in the least bit sticky, you've used too high heat, too much oil, or both, so strip it and start again.

It may take several rounds of seasoning to build up a truly non-stick skillet.

If something sticks to the skillet, let it cool down a bit, then use warm or hot water and a little baking soda and salt on a sponge or soft towel to clean it, then dry the skillet in a warm oven before re-seasoning the cast iron.

Never use any kind of soap or detergent to clean cast iron unless you intend to completely strip it and thoroughly re-season it.

Seasoning only stops water from getting in the pours and causing rust.

You gotta burn some oil to make a non-stick patina. The higher burning temperature, the better. Beef fat is best, peanuts for the vegitarians, and grapeseed for peanut free vegans. The oil will smoke, so it's best to use a covered pan in a well ventilated area.

Letting it cool slowly is essential. It allows the poly chains to bind to the different pour sizes in the iron. Covering the pan allows the smoke to create a fine patina.

Rinse and repeat for best results.

From when i worked on mould tooling, when we needed mirror finish, a trick was to always keep consistent directionality on your sanding, and alternate perpendicularly, so that your next grit goes in its cutting through the grooves on the previous one, instead of deepening it. Also, going by hand for the finer grits helps control the deeper grooves.

I'm a metallographer, our standard grit and polish progression is 60 grit to 120 grit, 320 grit, 600 grit, 1000 grit. We then will do .25 micron diamond paste, then a slurry of distilled water and alumina oxide powder. Lastly we will use a colloidal silica solution to take out any remain micro scratches. The cool thing about most cast irons is that they are really soft relative to alot of metals, which means that progressing through the rougher grits is easier. It's a pain later to keep them scratch free due to how soft the material is.

A lot of restaurants have polished cast iron flat tops that are nonstick- that's existence proof that it can be done. The surface polish is irrelevant, and so is "porosity"- that's a myth.
You screwed up by using vegetable oil. Use lard instead.

What you're trying to do is get the molecules of the seasoning material to lose everything but the carbon and the remaining carbon to *chemically bond to the iron*. That's why properly applied seasoning is almost impossible to remove and why almost nothing will stick to it.
Look at that layer- it's "bronze colored" instead of BLACK because it's *too thin*.

Vegetable oil melts and burns at too low a temperature to be ideal for seasoning- the carbon oxidizes away before it can all stick to the iron. That's why people have used lard for centuries when vegetable oils were also available.
If you don't have lard, use real butter (NOT margarine).
This is not about being PC or vegan, it's about the chemistry and physics of iron and carbon.

There are so many factors involved in making a successfuly seasoned pan. Type of oil, amount of oil used, heat levels, cool down rate, how many coats, non cooking fry coats etc. Even then, they need to be cleaned when cooled, no detergents and used frequently. There has been some research that a mirror level of surface smoothness is actually less effective than a slightly rough (satin finish)surface when it comes to getting the seasoning right.

The secret to cast iron eggs... 1. Season the pan with your oil of choice, this means a thin coat of oil and then heating it up till it smokes 2. Season the pan with butter, same story thin coat and heat till it smokes. After these 2 steps you can cook an oilless egg in a cast iron pan.

Season the pan a few more times and repeat till everything has a dull black finish.

Ok, part of the problem is that you're not seasoning properly.  Use solid fat, it sticks better, and get it hotter.  The brown color looks like you're not completely seasoning it.  It should be black.  You aren't cooking fat onto the pan, you're burning it.  Deliberately.  You're burning all of the hydrogen and oxygen off and leaving a layer of pretty much pure carbon.  That having been said, seasoning is only partially about making the pan non-stick.  It's mostly about sealing the metal away from oxygen to keep it from rusting.  Cast iron is a misnomer.  It's actually a really high carbon steel.  (Up to 4-5% carbon.)  Way TOO high to be useful for much, it's just too brittle at that point, and like all high carbon steel it's seriously vulnerable to rust.  There's no nickel or chromium in it to make it rust resistant.
